data.text: Is SP PD-8 Dynamo Hub Any Good?

data.text: Hard to help without some context. What are your requirements?

data.text: No idea, it would be my first time with a dynamo hub. ðŸ˜… I can just say that it will be on my Trek 520, so road touring bike and that I don't normally ride fast, like over 20 km/h...

data.text:
This is good value to compare hubs, as well as giving context to what they can do . Was watching last night actually. Agree with Russ, thereâ€™s lots of variables depending on what riding you are doing. Good luck. - https://youtu.be/hHwk7HhSado
How Much Do Dynamo Hubs Really Slow You Down?
youtube.com
data.author: Stephen Petty

data.text: I use Shimano hub 3w 6v and 21w 2usb solar charger and 21000mah power bank, This is what we need while bike touring.
data.author: ØºÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø¨ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø±Ø¶Ø§

data.text: This illustrates how feeble dynamo output is compared to the awesome capacity of lithium cells, and the power hunger of smartphones. It will take 35 hours of pedalling to charge the power bank using the dynamo, even if you ride fast enough to max out dynamo output the whole time, and every component is 100% efficient. (21Ah * 3600s * 5v / 3W = 126000 seconds to fully charge)
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: My dynamo connect to dynamo usb charger "Usb-Werk Busch & MÃ¼ller" My phone has 4300mah it takes 1h43m to charge 20% battery And this is very good for bike touring, The camera and flashlight batteries take much less time to charge, As for the powerbank, I only charge it at stations, restaurants, and sometimes people, Because even with home electricity, it takes a whole day to charge it. Generally I can't do without it, I use my dynamo for For lighting and charging.
data.author: ØºÙˆÙŠÙ„Ø¨ Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ Ø±Ø¶Ø§

data.text: Having owned a dynamo hub for a couple of years now I don't recommend getting one. They don't provide a useful amount of energy except as an emergency backup -- but in that case you should just pack an extra power bank. Far less money, weight and effort sucked out of your legs.
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: I had this hub. It worked, reliable no issues. I could definitely feel drag when charging, mine had an on/off switch on the light/usb port, and when you switched it was noticeable. They are useful for running lights, I had a pretty good front light, ok for night riding. However, for charging pretty marginal. I built a new touring bike without dynamo, and now just use power points and power banks where needed
data.author: Andrew Robinson

data.text: For running lights, it's great. But as noted, it doesn't put out a lot of power for charging. I have the SPV8 (for rim brakes). I ride daily and it's lasted well. I did send it back for bearing rebuild after a few years and they sent a new one. If you have a thru axle, make sure it's tight so the wires don't get yanked out. I like it for reliable lights and daytime running lights. I wouldn't use it to charge.
data.author: Pamela Murray

data.text: same experience, I paired the Dyno with the Sinewave Light because it has the USB output. My phone would stay about level for the day but wouldn't charge, I used a 20k mAH battery bank and a big blue folding solar panel....... It was plenty for two cameras and two phones and a flashlight.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: Does it have a drag if not powering anything?
data.author: Don Iverson

data.text: I don't notice it much. I think it's similar to carrying water or not. Not a big difference.
data.author: Pamela Murray

data.text: Great for powering lights, not so great for USB charging. This was my findings. Should explain, this is for all dynamo hubs, not just SP hubs
data.author: Paul Jordan

data.text: I use that dynamo with a sinewavw adaptor and it's fine with a flatter route, if it's hilly/mountainous and you're loaded up you won't get much use. Too slow on the ascents and the descents won't be long enough in time to get the charge in. Whether I use the dynamo or not mostly depends on route, power bank/banks tend to do the job
data.author: Jamie Ablitt

data.text: I have been using a solar panel (Goal Zero) for many years of touring and it works very well to keep my phone charged and a power pack. I have never been without power. I ride all over this blue marble, year-round, in all kinds of weather and the Goal Zero just keeps on working. I have studied power hubs extensively and find under touring conditions I just cannot maintain a high enough speed for them to function well. Power packs also can provide power if you can get to a grid place every few days.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I've used a number of sources over the years. I got turned on to dynamos on a tour through Germany about 7 years ago. I bought an entire system on the spot and sent my other wheel home. Since then I've had 3 of various. They worked fine and still do. They used to keep my GPS charged and still can keep a cell phone charged. But the electronics requirements of at least GPS devices has gotten more demanding and dynamos mostly can't charge them. It's now older technology. So last year I got a Pedal cell to try. And it's marvelous. There are many advantages. The biggest aside from it actually generating copious amounts of electricity is that it's easily disassembled and moved. Or disengage it for long uphills to eliminate resistance. Though it surprisingly works some even then. In any case you're not stuck with one wheel. I swap mine now and then. And it doesn't require a separate invertor. I've used a B&L and c2c. Both were fine. But the invertor is included in the Pedal cell. If you want a Dynamo I'll sell you one cheap. Same goes for an invertor. Message me if you do
data.author: Daniel Ellsworth

data.text:
I use this, non-dynamo, solution. It powers directly (no battery intermediary), and you can also disengage it while not in use. On a recent tour it kept my phone battery about even while pedaling over about 6 hours. I was using turn-by-turn navigation and playing music almost the whole time. https://pedalcell.com/
PedalCell - Bicycle Powered USB Charger
pedalcell.com
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: Works OK if touring away from regular (daily) access to electricity supplies. Pedalcell might be better option if have aluminium rims. SON option is more expensive but has better reputation especially if likely to be dunked or plan to fly with it. as others say is good for lights but need to ride a lot to add meaningful charge to phone or battery pack.
data.author: John Knapp
